A picaresque drama is ‚Äúa genre of prose fiction that depicts the adventures of a roguish, but appealing hero, of low social class, who lives by his wits in a corrupt society.‚Äù Think Robin Hood. Jacinto Benavente was an early 20th century Spanish dramatist who won the Nobel Prize for Literature in 1922. ‚ÄúThe Bonds of Interest‚Äù (published in 1908) is probably Benavente‚Äôs most famous play. The drama is picaresque in that the leading characters are devoid of wealth but (especially the servant, Crisp√≠n) possess their wealth in cunning. It has been called a ‚Äúfarce for puppets‚Äù where ‚Äúeverything happens in it that could never happen, its personages are not real men and women, nor the shadows of them, but dolls or marionettes of paste and cardboard, moving upon wires which are visible even in a little light and to the dimmest eye." The plot is both comical and chimerical, yet the underlying message regarding the meaning of life is quite serious. Benavente concludes his tale by reminding the audience, ‚Äúthere is something noble, something divine in our lives which is true and which is eternal, and which shall not close when the farce of life shall close.‚Äù
